questions.question_text: A network administrator is required to ensure that auditors have read-only access to the system logs, while systems administrators have read and write access to the system logs, and operators have no access to the system logs. The network administrator has configured security groups for each of these functional categories. Which of the following security capabilities will allow the network administrator to maintain these permissions with the LEAST administrative effort?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Role-based access

A. Mandatory access control
Mandatory access control (MAC) is a security model that relies on a central authority to assign security labels to objects and subjects, and to determine the rules governing access to those objects.
It is useful for highly sensitive systems and requires more administrative effort.

B. User-based permissions
User-based permissions assign permissions to individual users, it can be complex and more administrative effort to maintain when the number of users increases.

D. Least privilege
Least privilege is a security principle that limits users to the minimum set of permissions they need to perform their tasks. It is a good practice but it's not a security capability and it doesn't provide a way to manage permissions effectively.

Selected Answer: C
RBAC is an access model that is controlled by the system but focuses on a set of permissions versus an individual's permissions.

comments.content: I believe what you are looking for is here: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19253-01/816-4557/rbac-1/index.html#:~:text=With%20RBAC%2C%20you%20can%20enforce,necessary%20to%20perform%20a%20job.

discussion.content: why not least privilege?

To speed up resolution, the client will often store the results of resolution locally
(in the browser quite often) so that it does not have to query again if the same
resolution needs to be done. This is known as DNS caching, and this is also done
by caching nameservers (also known as recursive nameservers). Since it is
possible that values change (a different IP address issued to a host than it
previously had), caches typically come with TTL (time to live) values and time
out after a while.

Selected Answer: D
D. Time to live (TTL)

The Time to Live (TTL) value is a field in the DNS record that tells caching DNS servers how long they should keep the information in their cache before discarding it and requesting new information from the authoritative DNS server.

comments.content:
A. UDP forwarding
UDP forwarding is a technique used to forward packets from one network interface to another. It is not related to the update of MX records.

B. DNS caching
DNS caching is a technique used by DNS servers to temporarily store DNS query results to speed up subsequent requests for the same information. It is not related to expediting MX record updates.

C. Recursive lookup
Recursive lookup is a technique used by DNS resolvers to find the answer to a DNS query by querying other DNS servers on behalf of the client. It is not related to expediting MX record updates.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
TTL is used to grab the DNS records, without it the DNS cache is lost.

Selected Answer: D
A short TTL will force cache updates, expediting the propagation of DNS changes throughout the network.

Selected Answer: D
To expedite MX (Mail Exchanger) record updates to authoritative name servers (NSs), you can take several steps to help ensure that the changes are propagated as quickly as possible:

Lower the TTL (Time to Live): The TTL value in your DNS records determines how long DNS resolvers and caches should retain the information. By lowering the TTL for your MX records well in advance of making changes, you reduce the time it takes for DNS resolvers to update to the new MX record settings. A TTL value of 300 seconds (5 minutes) is a common choice.

It's important to note that DNS propagation is not instantaneous, and changes may take some time to reach all DNS resolvers on the internet. The exact time it takes for MX record updates to propagate can vary based on TTL settings and other factors. Lowering the TTL in advance, however, is a proactive step to help expedite the process.

GPT picks "(D) Time to live" and explains why:

"In simple terms, the "time to live" (TTL) is like a timer that tells other computers how long they can remember certain information, like where to find a website's email servers. When you want to update where those email servers are located (using MX records), you might set a low TTL. This short timer tells other computers to forget the old location quickly and ask for the new one. So, by using a low TTL, you can make sure that changes to your email servers are noticed and used by other computers more quickly."
i would go with B

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be used to expedite MX record updates to authoritative NSs?

discussion.content:
.AAAA record is used to find the IP address of a computer connected to the internet from a name.
.CNAME record is a type of DNS record that maps an alias name to a true or canonical domain name.
.MX record specifies the mail server responsible for accepting email messages on behalf of a domain name.
.SOA record is a type of resource record in the DNS containing administrative information about the zone.

Selected Answer: B
A CNAME record stands for "canonical name" record and is used to create an alias from one domain name to another domain name. It is commonly used when a domain owner wants a domain name to point to another domain name, instead of directly pointing to an IP address.
B - cname

Answer B
CNAME record maps alias name.
B CNAME

Selected Answer: B
It's definitely CNAME
B CNAME is correct

Selected Answer: B
Agree with B here. Canonical Name (CName) is an alias.
"AAAA" record points domain to IPv6 address. "A" record points domain to IPv4 address

Selected Answer: B
Right away it is CNAME. The question is pretty much the definition.

questions.question_text: Which of the following DNS records works as an alias to another record?

comments.content: I donâ€™t understand. If 255.255.255.0 gives 256 addresses. How does 255.255.254.0 give MORE addresses? Or 510? Please help

Thanks! I just thought about it and I think I'm making it too hard...
/24 = total 256 addresses. 
/23 = total 512 addresses 
/23 is in the 3rd octet and has 23 network bits and 9 host bits or 254. hence the answer being 255.255.254.0 or C.

/24 network makes 8 bits available for hosts (8 = 32-24). That has 2^8 possible combinations = 256, but the first and last not available so it is 256 - 2 = 254 available addresses.
One more bit makes it 2^9 and that is double (times 2) of 256 = 512. Again that is 510 available addresses. The explanation from Cyali is the easiest and logical. But if you want to remember how to remember then you need to read more on subnetting formulas.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The standard Class C subnet mask 255.255.255.0 gives you 256 addresses. Borrowing one more bit from the network portion doubles the address capacity (512). Subtract 2 for gateway/broadcast and you're at 510. The answer is 255.255.254.0

Hopefully this explanation helps someone out:

First, translate all of the subnet masks to CIDR notation

A. 255.255.0.0 = /16
B. 255.255.252.0 = /22
C. 255.255.254.0 = /23
D. 255.255.255.0 = /24

Subtract 32 from the CIDR notation. 

A. 32 - 16 = 16
B. 32 - 22 = 10
C. 32 - 23 = 9
D. 32 - 24 = 8

Apply the Power of 2 from the differences

A. 2^16 = 65,536
B. 2^10 = 1,024
C. 2^9 = 512
D. 2^8 = 256

Lastly subtract 2 to account for the reserved Network and Broadcast Address

A. 65,536 - 2 = 65,534
B. 1,024 - 2 = 1,022
C. 512 - 2 = 510
D. 256 - 2 = 254

The answer is C. This is the smallest amount subnet that has 510 usable addresses and fits the criteria for what they are looking for.

Selected Answer: C
2^9-2=510 so C is the answer
WHy did I use 9? 
0=8 bits
254=1 bit
so, 9 is the host bit
2^n-2= Number of the host
n: is the host bit

Selected Answer: B
C. Looks good. 
The subnet mask C (255.255.254.0), which corresponds to a /23 subnet, can support up to 510 hosts. This is not sufficient for 412 devices considering network and broadcast addresses are not usable for devices.

The subnet mask B (255.255.252.0), a /22 subnet, supports up to 1022 hosts, which is more than enough for 412 devices. Therefore, the original recommendation of subnet mask B (255.255.252.0) is the correct choice for accommodating 412 network-connected devices on the same subnet.

Estimated correctness: 95%

comments.content:
Nope its C. 412 hosts require 512 subnet, a /23 or in decimal 255.255.254.0
It goes 128 192 224 240 248 252 254 255
So 7 1s is 254

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
borrowing one extra bit from 3rd octet (making a /23 network) will give you 510 hosts. this is equivalent to 255.255.254.0 netmask.

I like how GPT explains it:
"To accommodate 412 network-connected devices on the same subnet while using the smallest possible subnet size, you need to calculate the appropriate subnet mask.

The formula to calculate the number of usable host addresses in a subnet is 2^(n) - 2, where 'n' is the number of bits borrowed from the host portion of the IP address to create the subnet.

You need at least 9 bits to accommodate 412 devices because 2^9 = 512, which is the smallest power of 2 that's greater than 412.However, we need to subtract 2 from the usable host addresses to account for the network address (all host bits set to 0) and the broadcast address (all host bits set to 1).

So, the number of usable addresses = 2^9 - 2 = 510.

The subnet mask would be 255.255.254.0 for a /23 subnet. 

This would give you a subnet that can accommodate 510 usable addresses, which should be sufficient for the 412 network-connected devices while keeping the subnet as small as possible.

Correct answer: C. 255.255.254.0

comments.content:
I do now, 255.255.255.0 gives you 256 free IP addresses
255.255.254.0 has a bit missing from the 3rd octet. So there's going to be 2 x 255.255.255.0 sets of addresses available (if that helps at all)

discussion.content: Don't understand it one bit

It's kind of simple to come from /24 network which makes 2^8-2 = 254 , /23 will make 2^9-2 = 510 hosts, which is correct answer. 
/23 is 254
That needs to be remembered

Selected Answer: C
To accommodate 412 network-connected devices, we need to select a subnet mask that provides at least 412 IP addresses. The smallest subnet mask that can achieve this is 255.255.254.0, which provides 510 IP addresses (512 - 2 reserved addresses). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

Selected Answer: C
255.255.254.0 is correct, I'm not sure why everyone is saying B. They need 412 devices, /23 is 512 possible devices. How do you figure 1024 from /22 is more efficient? C is the only correct answer if you want to limit it to as few addresses as possible.

Selected Answer: B
B. 255.255.252.0

The number of IP addresses in a subnet is determined by the number of bits used for the host portion of the IP address. The subnet mask used in this scenario should be as small as possible to accommodate the 412 devices.

A subnet mask of 255.255.252.0 has 22 bits for the host portion of the IP address, which can support up to 1022 IP addresses (2^22 - 2).

A. 255.255.0.0 has 16 bits for the host portion of IP address which support up to 65534 IP addresses.

C. 255.255.254.0 has 23 bits for the host portion of the IP address, which can support up to 510 IP addresses

D. 255.255.255.0 has 24 bits for the host portion of IP address which support up to 254 IP addresses

Therefore, using a subnet mask of 255.255.252.0 is the most efficient option for accommodating the IP addresses for 412 devices.

comments.content: You literally included the right answer in your reply, then noted the wrong answer. The question asks for the most efficient way to accommodate 412 addresses - the most efficient spot would be 510 addresses, 255.255.254.0
You can also just add 1 to the wildcard to get 2. Wildcard is just a humane way to calculate number of host per subnet.

discussion.content:
An class C give you at most 256 addresses including network ID and broadcast address. In this case, we need more than 256 addresses while being smallest thus we looking at class B of at least 2 host size.

With that said, option D is out because it is class C. Moving to the next smallest which is 255.255.254.0. Using wildcard which is reverse of CIDR and in this case 255 - 254 is 1 which means is 0.0.0.1. It also means it is 2 host size which give us 512 addresses. Why is it "2", because to get decimal 1 you will need an octet of 0000 0001 and applying the host formula of 2^1 = 2.

questions.question_text: A client moving into a new office wants the IP network set up to accommodate 412 network-connected devices that are all on the same subnet. The subnet needs to be as small as possible. Which of the following subnet masks should be used to achieve the required result?

A company is being acquired by a large corporation. As part of the acquisition process, the company's address should now redirect clients to the corporate organization page. Which of the following DNS records needs to be created?

discussion.content: CNAME can be used to direct an domain to another domain. You can do so with A or AAAA as well but it will be domain to an IP.

Selected Answer: C
C. CNAME (Canonical Name)

A CNAME record is used to create an alias for an existing DNS record. In this scenario, the company's address should redirect clients to the corporate organization page. A CNAME record can be created to point the company's DNS address to the corporate organization's DNS address.

A. SOA (Start of Authority) is a DNS record that contains information about the zone of authority, including the primary DNS server for the zone, the email address of the zone administrator, and other information about the zone.

B. NS (Name Server) is a DNS record that specifies the authoritative DNS servers for a domain.

D. TXT (Text) is a DNS record that can be used to store various types of text data, such as SPF (Sender Policy Framework) information, which can be used to prevent email spoofing.

Selected Answer: C
C - correct answer
